questions.questionsTitle: What will happen if microbes in the soil get destroyed?

subQuestion.question: What will happen if microbes in the soil get destroyed?
subQuestion.ans:
Certain bacteria and blue-green algae have the ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen.
This, in turn, enriches the fertility of the soil.
Such microorganisms are known as biological nitrogen fixers.
Example: Rhizobium is a symbiotic bacteria that lives in the root nodules of leguminous plants.
Rhizobium fixes atmospheric nitrogen into nitrogenous compounds.

questions.questionsTitle: How are we different from Oscillatory motion and linear motion?

subQuestion.question: How are we different from Oscillatory motion and linear motion?
subQuestion.ans: Oscillatory motionLinear motionThe type of motion in which the object moves to and fro repeatedly about a mean or a fixed position is known as oscillatory motion.The type of motion in which the object moves from one point to another in a straight line is called linear motion.In oscillatory motion, the body swings back and forth.In linear motion, an object shows displacement in a straight line.For example:Movement of the pendulum of a clockFor example:Vehicles moving on a straight road

subAns.Column 1: The type of motion in which the object moves to and fro repeatedly about a mean or a fixed position is known as oscillatory motion.
subAns.Column 2: The type of motion in which the object moves from one point to another in a straight line is called linear motion.

subAns.Column 1: In oscillatory motion, the body swings back and forth.
subAns.Column 2: In linear motion, an object shows displacement in a straight line.

subAns.Column 1: For example:Movement of the pendulum of a clock
subAns.Column 2: For example:Vehicles moving on a straight road

questions.questionsTitle: How are we different from linear motion and random motion?

subQuestion.question: How are we different from linear motion and random motion?

questions.questionsTitle: In what way are we different muscular force and mechanical force?

subQuestion.question: In what way are we different muscular force and mechanical force?
subQuestion.ans: Muscular forceMechanical forceThe force applied by the action of muscles in our body is termed as a muscular force.The force generated by the means of a machine is known as mechanical force.For example, when you pick up a book placed on the table using your hands, you apply muscular force.For example, when a car gets started, its engine creates a mechanical force on the tyres that help the car to accelerate.

subAns.Column 2: The force generated by the means of a machine is known as mechanical force.

subAns.Column 1: For example, when you pick up a book placed on the table using your hands, you apply muscular force.
subAns.Column 2: For example, when a car gets started, its engine creates a mechanical force on the tyres that help the car to accelerate. So here, the movement of the car occurs due to the force generated by the machine on the tyres.

questions.questionsTitle: In what way are we different the force of friction and gravitational force?

subQuestion.question: In what way are we different the force of friction and gravitational force?
subQuestion.ans: The force of frictionGravitational forceThe force which acts opposite to the direction of motion of a body is known as the force of friction.It is the force that is exerted by the earth on every object, which is near or on its surface.It is a contact type of force.It is a non-contact type of force.For example, a ball rolling on the ground stops after some time because of frictional force acting between the ground and the ball.For example, an apple falling from a tree branch towards the ground is due to gravitational force.

subAns.Column 1: The force which acts opposite to the direction of motion of a body is known as the force of friction.
subAns.Column 2: It is the force that is exerted by the earth on every object, which is near or on its surface.

subAns.Column 2: It is a non-contact type of force.

subAns.Column 1: For example, a ball rolling on the ground stops after some time because of frictional force acting between the ground and the ball.

questions.questionsTitle: In what way are we different muscular force and mechanical force?

subQuestion.question: In what way are we different muscular force and mechanical force?
subQuestion.ans: Muscular forceMechanical forceThe force applied by the action of muscles in our body is termed as a muscular force.The force generated by the means of a machine is known as mechanical force.For example, when you pick up a book placed on the table using your hands, you apply muscular force.For example, when a car gets started, its engine creates a mechanical force on the tyres that help the car to accelerate.

subAns.Column 1: The force applied by the action of muscles in our body is termed as a muscular force.
subAns.Column 2: The force generated by the means of a machine is known as mechanical force.

subAns.Column 1: For example, when you pick up a book placed on the table using your hands, you apply muscular force.
subAns.Column 2: For example, when a car gets started, its engine creates a mechanical force on the tyres that help the car to accelerate. So here, the movement of the car occurs due to the force generated by the machine on the tyres.

questions.questionsTitle: In what way are we different the force of friction and gravitational force?

subQuestion.question: In what way are we different the force of friction and gravitational force?
subQuestion.ans: The force of frictionGravitational forceThe force which acts opposite to the direction of motion of a body is known as the force of friction.It is the force that is exerted by the earth on every object, which is near or on its surface.It is a contact type of force.It is a non-contact type of force.For example, a ball rolling on the ground stops after some time because of frictional force acting between the ground and the ball.For example, an apple falling from a tree branch towards the ground is due to gravitational force.

subAns.Column 1: The force which acts opposite to the direction of motion of a body is known as the force of friction.
subAns.Column 2: It is the force that is exerted by the earth on every object, which is near or on its surface.

subAns.Column 1: It is a contact type of force.
subAns.Column 2: It is a non-contact type of force.

subAns.Column 1: For example, a ball rolling on the ground stops after some time because of frictional force acting between the ground and the ball.
subAns.Column 2: For example, an apple falling from a tree branch towards the ground is due to gravitational force.

questions.questionsTitle: What are the types of galaxies?

subQuestion.question: What are the types of galaxies?
subQuestion.ans:
Spiral Galaxies:These have spiral-shaped arms extending from a central bulge.
They contain stars, gas, and dust.Example:The Milky Way.

questions.questionsTitle: Which celestial bodies does a galaxy include?

subQuestion.question: Which celestial bodies does a galaxy include?
subQuestion.ans: A galaxy includes stars, cluster of stars, nebulae, clouds of gases and dusts, dead stars, newly born stars, etc.

questions.questionsTitle: Name the different types of stars.

subQuestion.question: Name the different types of stars.
subQuestion.ans:
Sun-like Stars:These are particularly similar to the Sun in size, but there is a lot of temperature variation.
Examples are Alpha Centauri, Tau Ceti, etc.

questions.questionsTitle: What are the types of comets and on what basis are they classified?

subQuestion.question: What are the types of comets and on what basis are they classified?
subQuestion.ans:
Long Period Comets: These comets complete one revolution around the Sun in 200 and more years.
The Great Comet of 1843 is one of the examples of this type.

questions.questionsTitle: What is the difference between meteors and meteorites?

subQuestion.question: What is the difference between meteors and meteorites?
subQuestion.ans:
Meteors:These are rocky pieces originating from the asteroid belt that enter the Earth's atmosphere as a result of its gravitational pull.
On entering the Earth's atmosphere, they acquire very high speeds.
These high speeds of meteors cause friction with the Earth's atmosphere and thus the meteors heat up and evaporate completely.
Meteors are also known as shooting stars.
